flowRoot.flowPara: TITLE
GOAL
STEPS
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
THE DATA ANALYSIS CHECKLIST
PURPOSE
What is this analysis supposed to achieve? What specific question am I trying to answer?

A well-defined goal is the anchor point of an analysis. It provides a foundation for the structure of your inquiry and allows you to gauge the utility of each potential addition to your analysis. Further, if your goal is poorly defined, how can you know if you've achieved it, or if it's time to stop and move onto something else?
Most analysis goals fall into one of the following categories:
Characterization
Answers the question: What are the basic scales, correlations and dimensionalities in my data?
Is appropriate when: First analyzing a dataset. However, simple characterization rarely leads to novel insights.
Exploration
Answers the question: Are there any obvious unexpected structural features in my data?

Is appropriate when: Ensuring your data has been collected properly and familiarizing oneself with the data beyond basic characterization. If nothing noteworthy emerges, however, one must decide whether to pursue more focused directions.
Hypothesis Test
Answers the question: Does my data support/refute a particular hypothesis?
Is appropriate when: A specific hypothesis has been suggested by either data exploration or known properties of related systems.
Hypothesis Comparison
Answers the question: Which of two or more hypotheses better explains my data?
Is appropriate when: Multiple hypotheses have been suggested by data exploration or the field at large, each of which one might reasonably imagine being true.
Prediction
Answers the question: How well can one set of features in my data be predicted from another?
Is appropriate when: One desires only better approximations of relationships, regardless of their internal details (typically in clinical or engineering applications).
EXPECTATION
What do I expect my results to look like? Can I imagine at least two reasonably likely outcomes?

This doesn’t mean your expectations will be met, of course, and a lot of good science emerges from observations no one had considered before. However, if you can’t think of anything that would be both meaningful and reasonably likely to observe you might want to rethink your plan.
VISUALIZATION
What plots or tables will I use to depict my results?

Imagining the end product of your analysis as precisely as possible provides a useful target for directing your methods. Good mock visualizations are also very useful for contextualizing your results before presenting them.
MEANING
Could I draw a meaningful conclusion from my expected results? Will they expand my understanding of the data? Will they reflect the structure of the data more than the structure of my analysis?

It is challenging to translate a plot or table into a meaningful statement about the underlying system, a statement that reveals subtleties of its composition or draws connections between components previously thought unrelated. In complex analyses especially, it can be quite laborious to identify how strongly the results have been influenced by the specifics of the analysis. For example, if your analysis segregates the data into clusters, it can be hard to discern whether the results reflect natural groupings vs. the definitions of your clustering criteria.
EXPLAINABILITY
Can I concisely explain my analysis so my audience understands and trusts it? If necessary, can I explain and justify every detail?

In the end you always have limited time to explain your analysis and convince your audience of its reasonability. A simple analysis that sacrifices a small amount of predictive power can thus be preferable to a more predictive but highly convoluted one, even if the latter is sound and logical.
PARAMETERS
How will I choose the parameters of my analysis and quantify my results’ dependence on them?

Almost all analyses require parameters choices, e.g. normalization factors, bin sizes, or smoothing scales, and these affect the results quantitatively. It can of course be inconvenient to re-run your analysis for every possible parameter combination, but you should be able to reasonably speak to the effect they have on the qualitative features of your results.
STATISTICS
How will I quantitatively argue my results didn’t arise by chance?
For extreme results this is often only a formality, but for subtler results statistical tests are key. These don’t have to generate p-values, but they should be mathematically interpretable.
CONFOUNDS
Could factors I don’t care about cause my expected results?

Naively interesting structures in a dataset often result from properties of the data irrelevant to your scientific question. For instance, the relationship between two variables might appear to change across conditions but actually be constant, with the apparent change arising from differences in the individual distributions of the variables, as opposed to how they relate. It can take a lot of thought to ensure your analysis controls for all important confounds.
CODE STRUCTURE
How will I write my code? How will I organize it?
CODE VALIDITY
What tests will I run to ensure my code works properly?

Just because your code doesn’t crash doesn’t mean it’s doing what you think it is. It’s crucial to verify its functionality with mock datasets or contexts where the ground truth results are known. Note that it’s common for tests to take up more than 50% of your code base.
CODE INTEGRATION
Once I write my basic code, how will I integrate my code it into my existing codebase?

This is an especially important in the highly iterative research process, in which one might run several variations of each unique analysis. While individual changes are often small, they can quickly tangle into a morass of complexity requiring large-scale refactoring to ensure cleanliness and readability. Importantly, while the heart of your code might be only a couple lines, one often requires a large infrastructure for file I/O, array manipulation, data reformatting, and auxiliary functions. While these are often conceptually straightforward, they can still be complicated and time-consuming to implement, and easily riddled with bugs.
RESULTS INTEGRATION
Where will I store my results so I can quickly access them later, recalling every detail if need be?

An analysis is only useful if you can recall it, even if it didn’t yield anything noteworthy. The copious analyses and variations in the research process make for a tangle not just of code, but of figures and tables too. Based on scientific developments or inquiries from colleagues, it is critical to be able to access each analysis you’ve performed in the past, along with the full results and methodology (including relevant code, should you decide to re-run or modify it) with a minimal amount of time and effort. As with code, when your set of results from different analyses reaches a critical mass, it can be valuable to reorganize.
RISKS
What parts of my analysis have I not yet figured out? How is my analysis most likely to fail?

You don’t need to flesh out every detail before starting, but you should estimate how much risk each unknown involves. These range from not knowing how to implement a particular computation, to not knowing how a certain aspect of the analysis will turn out that is necessary for continuation, to not knowing how likely it is your data will contain any evidence at all for a hypothesis, to not knowing how long your funding will persist. Isolate all uncertainties and failure points and either convince yourself of your ability to solve them or estimate the risk each one elicits to the success of your analysis as a whole and proceed accordingly.
TIME COST
How long will it take to complete the analysis from start to finish? To write the code? To run it? To test it? To organize and present the methods and results?

All analyses must be completed in a finite amount of time, and if you can judge how long something will take it will be much easier to decide whether to pursue it. This isn’t easy, but if you consider everything in this infographic, as you gain experience you will improve your ability to imagine everything involved from start to finish and to quantitatively estimate the time and resources required.
SIMPLICITY
Have I simplified everything as much as possible?

The simpler your analysis is, the easier everything above will be to address, the fewer headaches you’ll encounter, and the faster you’ll reach your goal. Complexity should only be added when it is purposeful and absolutely necessary to reach your analysis objective.
